options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They metabolize fats to produce energy.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They abandon their colony and find a new location with more oxygen.

options.label: D
options.text: They increase their food intake to produce more oxygen.

options.label: C

options.label: A
options.text: To encourage students to pursue STEM fields

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Can you solve the wizard standoff riddle? - Daniel Finkel

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of the Newt-niz sorcerer's wand turning people into fish?
Which wand has the highest casting effectiveness?
What happens if everyone is still standing at the end of the first round in the duel?
What is the probability of the Leib-ton enchantress' wand turning people into statues?
Which wand is chosen first by the champion, but later reconsidered?
What is the probability of the Gaussian wand turning one target into a tree?
What is the strategy employed by the champion to have the greatest chance of winning the duel?

options.label: A
options.text: Choose the Noether 9000 and target the most powerful opponent.

options.label: B
options.text: Choose the Gaussian and target the Leib-ton enchantress.

options.label: C
options.text: Choose the Bannekar and intentionally miss the target.

options.label: D
options.text: Choose the Newt-niz sorcerer's wand and target the Leib-ton enchantress.

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of the champion winning the duel if they choose the Bannekar wand and intentionally miss the target?
What is the probability of the sorcerer succeeding in turning the enchantress into a fish?
What is the outcome if the sorcerer fails to turn the enchantress into a fish?

options.label: A
options.text: The enchantress turns the sorcerer into stone.

options.label: B
options.text: The enchantress turns the champion into stone.

options.label: C
options.text: The champion has a higher chance of winning the duel.

title: Why do I have to use a number 2 pencil?

multiple-choice.question: Who devised a machine to score exams automatically in 1931?

options.label: A
options.text: Reynold Johnson, a high school physics teacher

options.label: B
options.text: A team of engineers at IBM

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why graphite is useful for scoring machines?

options.label: B
options.text: It is soft and easy to erase

options.label: C
options.text: It is hard and difficult to erase

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of phototubes in scoring machines?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect light in a certain spot

options.label: B
options.text: To detect darkness in a certain spot

multiple-choice.question: Why is graphite useful for blocking light in scoring machines?

options.label: A
options.text: It reflects most light and absorbs the rest

options.label: B
options.text: It absorbs most light and reflects the rest

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of clay in pencil manufacturing?

options.label: A
options.text: To control the color of the pencil lead

options.label: B
options.text: To control the hardness of the pencil lead

options.label: C
options.text: To control the softness and hardness of the graphite

options.label: D
options.text: To control the shape of the pencil

multiple-choice.question: What is the international equivalent of a number 2 pencil?
Why are number 2 pencils preferred for scoring machines?

options.label: A
options.text: They make marks that are too dark to be sensed by the machine

options.label: B
options.text: They make marks that are too light to be sensed by the machine

options.label: C
options.text: They make marks that are just dark enough to be sensed by the machine, but also light enough to be erased

options.label: D
options.text: They make marks that are too difficult to erase

multiple-choice.question: What type of sensors do modern scoring machines use?

options.label: C
options.text: Advanced sensors that can detect almost any sort of marks

multiple-choice.question: Who produced the first mark-sensing machines?
Why is it still recommended to use number 2 pencils for exams, despite modern scoring machines being able to detect almost any sort of marks?

title: Why are we ticklish?

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the itchy feeling you get when someone puts a feather on your sensitive skin?

options.label: D
options.text: Near the femoral artery in the leg

multiple-choice.question: According to some psychologists, what is the evolutionary purpose of gargalesis?

options.label: B
options.text: To teach young apes and humans how to protect themselves if attacked

options.label: C
options.text: To create a sense of playfulness

options.text: Getting answers to questions a little early

title: How old are your ears? (hearing test)

multiple-choice.question: What happens to our hearing spectrum as we grow older?

options.label: A
options.text: We gain the ability to hear higher frequencies.

options.label: B
options.text: We lose the extreme ends of our hearing spectrum.

options.label: C
options.text: Our hearing spectrum remains the same.

options.label: D
options.text: We gain the ability to hear lower frequencies.

multiple-choice.question: If you can hear 8,000 Hertz, what does it indicate about your hearing?

options.label: C
options.text: You are both alive and not hearing impaired.

options.label: D
options.text: You have a rare hearing condition.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated age limit for being able to hear all frequencies?
Which of the following organs has the capacity to regenerate?
Which of the following organs has the capacity to regenerate, unlike the inner ear?
What are the tiny nerve cells in the ear responsible for picking up different frequencies called?
What happens to the hair cells in the ear as we age?
Why do the hair cells tuned to high pitches degenerate earlier?

options.label: C
options.text: They are the first to encounter sound waves and experience more stress.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the last to encounter sound waves and experience less stress.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the hair cells degenerating?
Where are sound signals sent after being picked up by the hair cells?
Why do older people tend to have a harder time hearing high pitches?

options.label: A
options.text: The hair cells tuned to high pitches are the last to degenerate.

options.label: B
options.text: The hair cells tuned to high pitches are the first to degenerate.

options.label: C
options.text: The inner ear regenerates as we age.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain becomes less sensitive to sound.

title: What if you never forgot anything?

multiple-choice.question: According to Sherlock Holmes, what is the brain's capacity for storing memories like?

options.label: A
options.text: A library with an infinite number of books

options.label: B
options.text: A computer with limited storage capacity

options.label: C
options.text: A muscle that can be strengthened with exercise

options.label: D
options.text: A container that can be filled and emptied at will

multiple-choice.question: What is the reality of how memories are stored in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Memories are stored in a single location in the brain

options.label: B
options.text: Memories are scattered throughout the brain and involve multiple brain cells

options.label: C
options.text: Memories are stored in a specific lobe of the brain

options.label: D
options.text: Memories are not stored in the brain at all

multiple-choice.question: What is the hippocampus, and what is its role in memory formation?

options.label: A
options.text: The hippocampus is a part of the brain that stores memories, and it is responsible for forming new memories

options.label: B
options.text: The hippocampus is a part of the brain that helps to form new memories, but it is not where memories are stored

options.label: C
options.text: The hippocampus is a part of the brain that is responsible for forgetting memories

options.label: D
options.text: The hippocampus is not a part of the brain at all

multiple-choice.question: What is consolidation, and how does it relate to memory formation?

options.label: A
options.text: Consolidation is the process of forgetting memories, and it occurs when brain cells are not used

options.label: B
options.text: Consolidation is the process of forming new memories, and it occurs when brain cells are active

options.label: C
options.text: Consolidation is the process of replaying experiences in the brain to strengthen connections between cells

options.label: D
options.text: Consolidation is not a real process in the brain

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between passive oblivescence and targeted forgetting?

options.label: A
options.text: Passive oblivescence is the process of forgetting memories over time, while targeted forgetting is the process of intentionally suppressing memories

options.label: B
options.text: Passive oblivescence is the process of intentionally suppressing memories, while targeted forgetting is the process of forgetting memories over time

options.label: C
options.text: Passive oblivescence is the process of forming new memories, while targeted forgetting is the process of forgetting old memories

options.label: D
options.text: Passive oblivescence and targeted forgetting are the same thing

multiple-choice.question: What is motivated forgetting, and why is it important?

options.label: A
options.text: Motivated forgetting is the process of intentionally suppressing memories, and it is important for maintaining a positive self-image

options.label: B
options.text: Motivated forgetting is the process of forgetting memories over time, and it is important for clearing out useless information

options.label: C
options.text: Motivated forgetting is the process of forming new memories, and it is important for learning and growth

options.label: D
options.text: Motivated forgetting is not a real process in the brain

multiple-choice.question: What is hyperthymesia, and what are its effects on a person's life?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperthymesia is a condition where a person has a perfect memory, and it can be beneficial for learning and growth

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperthymesia is a condition where a person has a poor memory, and it can be detrimental to their daily life

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperthymesia is a condition where a person has a perfect memory, but it can also be a curse, causing them to be haunted by upsetting memories

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperthymesia is not a real condition

multiple-choice.question: What is electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), and how does it affect memory?

options.label: A
options.text: ECT is a treatment that can erase specific memories, and it is often used to treat patients with painful memories

options.label: B
options.text: ECT is a treatment that can improve memory, and it is often used to treat patients with memory loss

options.label: C
options.text: ECT is a treatment that can cause memory loss, and it is often used to treat patients with severe mental health conditions

options.label: D
options.text: ECT is not a real treatment

multiple-choice.question: Why is forgetting important for our brains and our lives?

options.label: A
options.text: Forgetting is important because it allows us to clear out useless information and make room for new memories

options.label: B
options.text: Forgetting is important because it allows us to remember every detail of our lives

options.label: C
options.text: Forgetting is important because it allows us to learn and grow

options.label: D
options.text: Forgetting is not important at all

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between memorization and learning?

options.label: A
options.text: Memorization is the same as learning, and it is the best way to acquire new knowledge

options.label: B
options.text: Memorization is not the same as learning, and it is only one part of the learning process

options.label: C
options.text: Memorization is not important for learning, and it is a waste of time

options.label: D
options.text: Memorization is the only way to learn new things

title: How to tame your wandering mind

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what percentage of brain capacity do human beings use?

options.label: A
options.text: A way to process information more slowly

options.label: B
options.text: A solution to the problem of information overload

options.label: B
options.text: A type of brain wave associated with attention

options.label: C
options.text: A type of brain wave associated with face detection

options.label: D
options.text: A type of brain wave associated with memory

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on attention

options.label: D
options.text: It only affects attention in certain situations

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is mind-wandering?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The act of focusing on a single task

options.label: C
options.text: The act of having off-task thoughts while engaged in an ongoing task

multiple-choice.question: What is the opposite of a stressed and wandering mind, according to the speaker?

options.label: C
options.text: It protects against lapses in attention

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on attention

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of offering mindfulness training to high-stress groups, according to the speaker?

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to benefiting from mindfulness training?

options.label: C

title: When will the next ice age happen? - Lorraine Lisiecki

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used by geologists to describe the most recent time that ice reached a huge extent on Earth, about 20,000 years ago?
How many glacial maxima have occurred over the last million years?
What was the state of the Earth's polar ice caps for hundreds of millions of years?

options.label: C
options.text: They were the same size as today

options.label: D
options.text: They were only at the North Pole

multiple-choice.question: What event occurred about 700 million years ago when the Earth became almost entirely covered in ice?
What is one of the main drivers of massive swings in the Earth's climate?

options.label: A
options.text: Volcanism and chemical weathering of rocks

options.label: B
options.text: Volcanism and the burial of organic matter

options.label: C
options.text: Volcanism, chemical weathering of rocks, and the burial of organic matter

options.label: D
options.text: Only the burial of organic matter

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected rise in sea level by the end of this century due to ice melt?

options.text: Only reduce carbon dioxide emissions gradually
